sample_rows.PRODUCT: Credit reporting, credit repair services, or other personal consumer reports
sample_rows.ISSUE: Problem with a credit reporting company's investigation into an existing problem
sample_rows.SUB_ISSUE: Difficulty submitting a dispute or getting information about a dispute over the phone
sample_rows.COMPANY_PUBLIC_RESPONSE: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

sample_rows.PRODUCT: Credit reporting, credit repair services, or other personal consumer reports
sample_rows.ISSUE: Problem with a credit reporting company's investigation into an existing problem
sample_rows.COMPANY_PUBLIC_RESPONSE: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

sample_rows.SUB_ISSUE: Didn't receive enough information to verify debt
sample_rows.CONSUMER_COMPLAINT_NARRATIVE:
On or about XX/XX/2016, I received notification on my credit report through XXXX  XXXX  that Receivables Management from what appears to be XXXX XXXX as the original creditor. However, XXXX XXXX is a urgent care facility and this debt has been PAID IN FULL -- as they will not treat a patient ( my minor daughter ), if there are ANY OUTSTANDING DEBTS on the account. This account was paid when I visited XXXX XXXX again with my daughter. 

Receivables Management Systems did not provide enough information on my credit report for me to VERIFY the debt. For example, there is NO ACCOUNT NUMBER referenced, no " TYPE '' of accou8nt, and I've repeatedly tried to DISPUTE this account with both XXXX and XXXX on numerous occasions. 

So let me ask, if there is NO WAY for a consumer to reference an account number to any payments made, how are ANY accounts being appropriately debited for payments received by consumers? 

Should the CFPB allow Receivables Management Systems to continue to collect debt and falsify credit reports of consumers by making it impossible for consumers to prove their debt with this collection agency has been resolved, paid in full, or even settled? If there is no account numbers reported, this company can literally be accepting payments from consumers all across the USA and never reflecting the payment ( s ) on their accounts.

XXXX   has had this dispute open for SEVERAL MONTHS without resolve. 

Is there a law regarding how long a company has to prove a dispute to be correct or incorrect? I thought this federal law was 30 days??? Why is this company STILL REPORTING I OWE MONEY TO THEM on two out of three credit reporting companies?

And in addition to all of this, when you go to their website http : //rmscollect.com/ and click on PAY ONLINE, the very 1st question is " Account Number '' -- and it's a required field to move forward. This collection has been on my credit report FOR THREE YEARS -- even though I've continuously disputed it -- and it has NEVER REPORTED an account number.

sample_rows.PRODUCT: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
sample_rows.SUB_ISSUE: Reporting company used your report improperly

description: Date the CFPB sent the complaint to the company
Indicates whether the company gave a timely response
mailing zip code provided by the consumer
type of sub-issue identified by the consumer in the complaint.  The categorical sub-issues available for selection have evolved over time
a unique identifier of the mailing state provided by the consumer
Date the CFPB received the complaint
The optional, public-facing response to a consumer complaint chosen by the company from a list
The consumer-submitted description of the complaint, with PII scrubbed by the CFPB.  Consumers must opt-in and can opt out at any time
mailing state provided by the consumer
a unique identifier of the mailing zip code provided by the consumer
Company identified by the consumer in the complaint.
type of sub-product identified by the consumer in the complaint.  Sub-product categories were consolidated by the CFPB in 2017
type of issue identified by the consumer in the complaint.  The categorical issues available for selection have evolved over time
Company explanation of how the issue was closed, selected from a list
Whether the consumer disputed the company response.  After April 24, 2017 the Bureau discontinued this option and this field is marked N/A
Identifies consumer consent in publishing their complaint narrative
type of product identified by the consumer in the complaint.  Product categories were consolidated by the CFPB in 2017
Categorical data supporting easier searching of complaints submitted by or on behalf of consumers, includes "Older American" and "Servicemember"
